Award.AbstractNarration: Since 2003, the ACM International Conference on Embedded Networked Sensor Systems (SenSys) has served as a high caliber, cross disciplinary forum for research on systems issues in embedded and networked sensors. SenSys, a single track forum, addresses issues that span multiple research areas, including wireless communication, networking, operating systems, architecture, low power circuits, distributed algorithms, data processing, scheduling, sensors, energy harvesting, and signal processing. Student participation in top research venues, such as SenSys, is critical for a vibrant research community. Further, students often have limited sources of funds to travel to conferences. Bringing students together with experienced practitioners enriches existing research projects and creates new collaborations. Travel grants will be awarded based on need. This award will support to cover travel and conference registration expenses for twenty students and help increase the representation and participation of graduate students in SenSys.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided partial financial support for 25 students to attend the 9th ACM Conference on Embedded Networked Sensor Systems (SenSys), held November 1-4, 2011 in Seattle, WA, USA.

Since 2003, SenSys (http://sensys.acm.org) has served as a high caliber, cross disciplinary forum for research on systems issues in embedded and networked sensors. SenSys, a single track forum, addresses issues that span multiple research areas, including wireless communication, networking, operating systems, architecture, low power circuits, distributed algorithms, data processing, scheduling, sensors, energy harvesting, and signal processing. Student participation in top research venues, such as SenSys, is critical for a vibrant research community. Further, students often have limited sources of funds to travel to conferences. This project helped increase the representation and participation of graduate students in SenSys.

For selecting the awardees, the committee gave priority to female and under-represented minority students, as well as students pursuing their graduate studies in Minority Serving Institutions (such as, Historically Black Universities, Hispanic Serving Institutions, Tribal Colleges and Universities), and institutions that serve Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders and persons with disabilities. From this award the following had benefited: 5 female and under-represented/minority students and 10 under-represented institutions.

Students that benefitted from this Travel Award have improved their research and teaching skills through discussion with peer researchers and presentation of their ideas and research directions. Students that benefitted from this Travel Award have also participated in demonstrations of their research (i.e., prototype implementations). Throughout the years, several of demonstrations that appeared at SenSys have resulted in commercial products by startup companies formed by former student researchers. One example is Sentilla Corporation, formed by a group of graduate students from UC Berkeley.

The feedback from the students was extremely positive, as exemplified below.

Matt Keally (PhD student at College of William and Mary): "Receipt of the NSF Travel Award allowed me to travel to SenSys and meet with top sensor networking and mobile computing professionals in both industry and academia. I received excellent feedback on my research in body sensor networks and gained inspiration for future research based on the presentations and demos. Furthermore, I made contacts with potential collaborators and employers to aid not only my career but also to aid the future of sensor network research."

Jing (Selena) He (female PhD student at Georgia State University): “During the conference, I listened the interesting presentation from the keynote speaker Dr. Michel Maharbiz, whose Ph.D work leads to the foundation of Micro-reactor Technologies. My current research works are mainly focus on the theoretical analysis instead of the system implementation. After listening to this presentation, I am very interest in the real system implementation. Moreover, I watched lots of demonstrations shown in the conference. By knowing more about the real systems, I grasp the gaps between the theoretical research and the system implementation, which is critical to my future researches. Additionally, many novel and advanced techniques are delivered on this conference. I learned the latest developments and trends in this field. Finally, I have a great opportunity to know worldwide experts and researchers, to communicate with them and learn from them.”

With its diverse, strong, program spanning full research papers, demonstrations, posters, and three workshops, SenSys 2011 attracted the next wave of young researchers to a field with bold and visionary goals.
